title: How to Clean with Olive Oil

steps.headline: Wash paint-covered area.
steps.description: Before applying the oil, give the paint-affected area(s) a good scrubbing. Use soft and warm water to remove excess paint and any remaining debris.

steps.headline: Pour olive oil into a clean cloth.
steps.description: Keep the area mess free by placing the rag over the olive oil bottle mouth and turn the olive oil upside down. Saturate the cloth with oil, but not too much so that it drips from the cloth.

steps.headline: Rub oil on paint-covered skin until dried paint is lifted from the skin.
steps.description:
If paint does not come off the skin with olive oil alone, add a pinch of salt to the olive oil solution to use as an exfoliate. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/1\/19\/Clean-with-Olive-Oil-Step-3Bullet1.jpg\/v4-459px-Clean-with-Olive-Oil-Step-3Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/1\/19\/Clean-with-Olive-Oil-Step-3Bullet1.jpg\/v4-759px-Clean-with-Olive-Oil-Step-3Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868134,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>

\n<\/p><\/div>"}

steps.headline: Remove dust from furniture using a clean micro-fiber cloth.
steps.description: For best results and shine, you should first remove dust and debris from the furniture.

steps.headline: Combine 3 parts olive oil and 1 part lemon juice in a bottle.
steps.description: Mix well so that the lemon juice is fully integrated into the oil.

steps.headline: Cover a clean cotton cloth with the oil and lemon mixture.
steps.description: Don’t over-saturate, but just cover the cloth so that the oil is transferred to the furniture.

steps.headline: Rub cloth on wood furniture until furniture is polished.
steps.description:
Consider testing the mixture in a hidden area of the furniture before using to ensure it doesn’t stain or discolor the furniture. Consider using olive oil (only) on leather furniture. Place a small amount on a clean cloth and rub on leather. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/a\/a0\/Clean-with-Olive-Oil-Step-7Bullet1.jpg\/v4-459px-Clean-with-Olive-Oil-Step-7Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/a\/a0\/Clean-with-Olive-Oil-Step-7Bullet1.jpg\/v4-759px-Clean-with-Olive-Oil-Step-7Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868134,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"}

steps.headline: Pour olive oil into a small bottle.
steps.description: Considering using a spray bottle with a “spray” setting (not mist).

steps.headline: Spray directly on squeaky area and follow with a cotton ball to remove residue.
steps.description: Use a small amount to avoid having the oil drip.

steps.headline: Test hinge and either apply more oil or wipe residual oil from the hinge.
Remove dust or any debris from item.
steps.description: Use a microfiber cloth to lift dust from item. Once debris has been lifted, rub the surface with clean cloth.

steps.headline: Dab a little olive oil on a clean cotton cloth and rub in a circular motion over the item.
steps.description: Use a small amount of oil in order to achieve a shine.

steps.headline: Follow up with a clean cloth to remove excess oil and further the shine on the item.
Dab olive oil on a clean cloth and apply directly to the sticker surface.
steps.description: Make sure you have enough oil to cover the sticker. Even a little excess oil may be necessary.

steps.headline: Rub the oil in a circular motion over the sticker and allow the oil to sit for a few minutes.
Run your fingernail underneath the sticker or price tag to lift the sticker from the surface.
steps.description: Re-apply oil if the sticker is not lifting with ease.

text:
Remove Paint from Skin Wash paint-covered area. Before applying the oil, give the paint-affected area(s) a good scrubbing. Use soft and warm water to remove excess paint and any remaining debris. Pour olive oil into a clean cloth. Keep the area mess free by placing the rag over the olive oil bottle mouth and turn the olive oil upside down. Saturate the cloth with oil, but not too much so that it drips from the cloth. Rub oil on paint-covered skin until dried paint is lifted from the skin. If paint does not come off the skin with olive oil alone, add a pinch of salt to the olive oil solution to use as an exfoliate. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/19/Clean-with-Olive-Oil-Step-3Bullet1.jpg/v4-459px-Clean-with-Olive-Oil-Step-3Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/19/Clean-with-Olive-Oil-Step-3Bullet1.jpg/v4-759px-Clean-with-Olive-Oil-Step-3Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868134,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Polish and Shine Wood Furniture Remove dust from furniture using a clean micro-fiber cloth. For best results and shine, you should first remove dust and debris from the furniture. Combine 3 parts olive oil and 1 part lemon juice in a bottle. Mix well so that the lemon juice is fully integrated into the oil. Cover a clean cotton cloth with the oil and lemon mixture. Don’t over-saturate, but just cover the cloth so that the oil is transferred to the furniture. Rub cloth on wood furniture until furniture is polished. Consider testing the mixture in a hidden area of the furniture before using to ensure it doesn’t stain or discolor the furniture. Consider using olive oil (only) on leather furniture. Place a small amount on a clean cloth and rub on leather. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a0/Clean-with-Olive-Oil-Step-7Bullet1.jpg/v4-459px-Clean-with-Olive-Oil-Step-7Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a0/Clean-with-Olive-Oil-Step-7Bullet1.jpg/v4-759px-Clean-with-Olive-Oil-Step-7Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868134,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Lubricate Squeaky Doors Pour olive oil into a small bottle. Considering using a spray bottle with a “spray” setting (not mist). Spray directly on squeaky area and follow with a cotton ball to remove residue. Use a small amount to avoid having the oil drip. Test hinge and either apply more oil or wipe residual oil from the hinge. Shine Stainless Steal or Brass Remove dust or any debris from item. Use a microfiber cloth to lift dust from item. Once debris has been lifted, rub the surface with clean cloth. Dab a little olive oil on a clean cotton cloth and rub in a circular motion over the item. Use a small amount of oil in order to achieve a shine. Follow up with a clean cloth to remove excess oil and further the shine on the item. Remove Stickers or Price Tags Dab olive oil on a clean cloth and apply directly to the sticker surface. Make sure you have enough oil to cover the sticker. Even a little excess oil may be necessary. Rub the oil in a circular motion over the sticker and allow the oil to sit for a few minutes. Run your fingernail underneath the sticker or price tag to lift the sticker from the surface. Re-apply oil if the sticker is not lifting with ease.
